children.name: the true information or facts about sth
the truth
children.definition: the true facts about something, rather than what is untrue, imagined, or guessedOPP lie,falsehood,untruth: sự thật
examples: How do we know you’re telling us the truth?
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say 'say the truth'. Saytell the truth.

children.name: tell the truth
examples: It's better to tell the truth.

children.name: speak the truth
examples: He always spoke the truth, whether it was popular or not.

children.name: know the truth
examples: At last I knew the truth about my father’s death.

children.name: find out/discover/uncover the truth
examples: She was determined to find out the truth.

children.name: learn the truth
examples: When she learns the truth, she may decide to help us.

children.name: get at/to the truthinformal
children.definition: discover the truth
examples: The police will eventually get to the truth of the matter.

children.name: reveal the truth
examples: She’d promised never to reveal the truth.

children.name: accept/admit the truth
examples: Our pride kept us from admitting the truth.

children.name: be/come close to the truth
examples: The book comes a little too close to the truth for their liking.

children.name: get the truth out of somebody
children.definition: make someone tell you the truth
examples: I’ll get the truth out of her, whatever it takes!

children.name: the whole/full truth
examples: Investors should have been told the whole truth.

children.name: the simple/plain/naked truth
children.definition: the truth, with nothing added, left out, or hidden
examples: The simple truth is that there isn’t enough money to pay for it.

children.name: the sad/painful truth
children.definition: something that is true but that you regret
examples: She still misses him, and that’s the sad truth.

children.name: the awful/terrible/dreadful etc truth
examples: She could not bring herself to tell them the awful truth.

children.name: the honest truth
children.definition: used to emphasize that you are telling the truth
examples: We never came here to steal anything, and that’s the honest truth.

children.name: the gospel truth
children.definition: the complete truth
examples: Don’t take everything she says as the gospel truth.

children.name: the truth of the matter
examples: The truth of the matter is that we don’t know what really happened.

children.name: the truth about
examples: She hoped to find out the truth about her family.

children.name: the truth behind
examples: We’ll never know the truth behind what happened.

children.name: the truth comes outthe truth becomes known
examples: Nixon tried to cover up the burglary, but the truth had to come out in the end.

children.name: the truth is (that)
examples: The truth is that the idea of having kids terrifies him.

children.name: fact
children.definition: a piece of information that is known to be true: sự thật (thông tin thật)
examples: The most important thing is to find out what the facts are and put the scandal behind us.
Gentry still owed Mr Tilly $7,000, a fact he failed to mention when he was arrested.
fact about
The book is full of facts about the World Cup.
fact of
First of all, we need to know the facts of the case.
fact that
It is a fact that the world is round.
it’s a fact/that’s a fact(= used to emphasize that something is definitely true or that something definitely happened )
The divorce rate is twice as high as in the 1950s – that’s a fact.
is that a fact?(= used to reply to a statement that you find surprising, interesting, or difficult to believe )
‘She used to be a professional singer.’ ‘Is that a fact?’

children.name: the basic/key facts
examples: The report outlines the basic facts concerning the case.

children.name: a well-known fact
examples: It is a well-known fact that new cars lose a lot of their value in the first year.

children.name: a little-known fact
examples: It is a little-known fact that the actor was born in London.

children.name: an interesting fact
examples: The research revealed some interesting facts about the behaviour of cats.

children.name: a curious/remarkable fact
examples: It is a remarkable fact that elephants do not use their trunks to suck up water until they are over four months old.

children.name: hard facts
children.definition: information that is definitely true and can be proven
examples: His theory is supported by hard facts.

children.name: a historical/scientific fact
examples: This was presented as a historical fact when it was just an opinion.

children.name: the bare facts
children.definition: only the basic general facts of a situation
examples: We know the bare facts of his life, but nothing about what he was really like.

children.name: give sb/provide the facts
examples: Newspapers have a duty to give their readers the facts.

children.name: establish/piece together the facts
children.definition: find out what actually happened in a situation
examples: The police are still piecing together the facts.

children.name: examine the facts
examples: I decided to examine the facts for myself.

children.name: state the facts
children.definition: say what you know is true
examples: Press reports often fail to state the facts completely.

children.name: stick to the facts
children.definition: say only what you know is true
examples: Just stick to the facts when the police interview you.

children.name: know for a fact
children.definition: used to say that something is definitely true
examples: I know for a fact that she is older than me.

children.name: get your facts right/straight
children.definition: make sure that what you say or believe is correct
examples: You should get your facts straight before making accusations.

children.name: get your facts wrong
examples: It’s no use putting together a beautifully-written argument if you get your facts wrong.

children.name: truth
children.definition: an important fact or idea that is accepted as being true: sự thật

children.name: fundamental truths about human nature
examples: The experience has taught us somebasic truths.

children.name: an unhappy/unpleasant/unwelcome truth(= an unpleasant or disappointing fact )
examples: It is in his interest to hide unhappy truths about his agency’s performance.

children.name: home truths
children.definition: UK facts about sb which are unpleasant for them to know but are true: sự thật chua xót ( về ai )
examples: It’s about time someone told that woman a few home truths.

children.name: reality
children.definition: a fact
examples: political/social/economic realitiesHe's ignoring political realities.

children.name: become a reality(= really happen, after being hoped for, feared, etc by someone )
examples: Last June, her longed-for baby finally became a reality.
The paperless office may one day become a reality .

children.name: truth
children.definition: the state or quality of being true: tính chân thật

children.name: truth in
examples: There was some truth in the accusations.

children.name: grain/element of truth(= small amount of truth )
examples: There wasn’t a grain of truth in what he said.
There was an element of truth(= a small amount of truth )in what he said.
There is no truth in the rumour.

children.name: reality
children.definition: the state of things as they are, rather than as they are imagined to be
examples: the distinction between fantasy and reality
the reality is that
The reality is that young people will not go into teaching until salaries are higher.

children.name: the harsh/grim/stark reality
children.definition: conditions that are really very bad
examples: We want to protect our children from the harsh reality of our violent world.

children.name: face reality
children.definition: accept it
examples: It's painful, but you have to face reality.

children.name: confront a reality
children.definition: consider or deal with it
examples: They had to confront some unpleasant realities about themselves.

children.name: ignore a reality
examples: They are ignoring the reality of Arab politics.

children.name: wake up to reality
children.definition: realize what is happening or real
examples: Well, they need to wake up to reality.

children.name: lose touch with reality
children.definition: no longer know about ordinary things or what is possible
examples: If all you have is the show-business world, you kind of lose touch with reality.

children.name: escape from reality
examples: The programmes help viewers escape from reality.

children.name: bring sb back to reality
children.definition: make them realize what is happening around them or true
examples: She was brought back to reality by the pain in her ankle.

children.name: reflect reality
children.definition: match or show what is really happening or true
examples: Do these novels accurately reflect contemporary reality?

children.name: bear no relation to reality
children.definition: not match what is really happening or true
examples: His vision of European politics bears no relation to reality.

children.name: be divorced from reality
children.definition: not connected in any way to what is really happening
examples: His ideas are completely divorced from reality.

children.name: a dose of reality
children.definition: an experience of what things are really like
examples: I got my first dose of reality when I reported to work at my new job.

children.name: sb’s grasp of reality
children.definition: their understanding of reality
examples: They portrayed her as a sick woman with only a tenuous grasp of reality.
